newsitem.title: USA: Conn. lawmaker seeks more money from NHL Whalers.
newsitem.headline: Conn. lawmaker seeks more money from NHL Whalers.

text.p: Connecticut House of Representatives Speaker Tom Ritter said Wednesday the state should demand a much higher exit fee from the Hartford Whalers than the $20.5 million arranged last week.

Peter Karmanos, who owns the National Hockey League (NHL) franchise, last week rejected Connecticut Governor John Rowland's proposal to build a $147 million arena and said the team would leave the state at the end of this season.
Rowland, a Republican, said last week the team agreed to pay $20.5 million as an exit fee, because under their contract with the state, they were to stay for at least one more season.
"Let's go back to the table and tell them that we're going to put the hammer to their heads," Ritter said in an interview broadcast on local radio.
"We're going to force our rights under the contract to make them stay here next year, unless they make it so inviting by the payment they're going to give us..."
Ritter, a Democrat, said the exit fee should be increased at least two-fold.
He also said the state should wait until the last possible moment to agree on an exit fee.
A group of Hartford business and political leaders are still trying to broker a last-ditch deal to keep the team -- Connecticut's only major league sports franchise -- in the capital city.
Hartford Mayor Mike Peters said Tuesday the city was considering a lawsuit to keep the team here for the final season of its Civic Center lease.
Hartford owns the Civic Center and leases it to the Connecticut Development Authority.
But analysts point out that a lawsuit would not endear the capital city to Rowland as budget season approaches. The state funds nearly half of Hartford's $414 million budget.

Karmanos has not said where the Whalers, who came to Hartford in 1975, will relocate. Among the cities seen as contenders are Minneapolis/St. Paul, Minn.; Columbus, Ohio; Nashville, and Oklahoma City.
